instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2442: What is A2442? A2442 is a model number for a 14 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2021 M1 with EMC 3650, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02098..
definitions.820-02098: What is 820-02098? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
Came in with a little teeny tiny speck of dust on <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R9310</RESISTOR> resistor above it.
Removed the chip, cleaned it up and install new resistors and few caps around it.. still 5V..
I took few measurements
[B]PPDCIN[/B] 5V (diode mode good according to OBD)
[B]PPBUS[/B] 12.27V (diode mode good according to OBD)
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL>[/B] 3.8V (diode mode good according to OBD)
[B]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AON</SIGNAL>[/B] 1.8V
[B]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2_MAIN</SIGNAL>[/B] was 2.9v and unstable goes up and down.. (diode mode: 0.406, it seems good as well) 
I took off <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> suspecting maybe its pulling 5V S2 down.. but still 5V S2 was fluctuating..
To save time I changed UC260 ([B]5V S2 VR[/B]) directly.. and still 5V S2 was fluctuating..

I measured the enable signal ([B]<SIGNAL>P5VS2_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>[/B]) and it was low (0.550v) and unstable as well.. and it comes from MPMU <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>..
I measured [B]<SIGNAL>IPD_PWR_EN_PMU</SIGNAL>[/B] and it was absent.. [B]<SIGNAL>IPD_PWR_HOLD</SIGNAL>[/B] was absent too.

[B]<SIGNAL>5VS2_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>[/B] diode 0.714
[B]<SIGNAL>IPD_PWR_EN_PMU</SIGNAL> [/B]diode 0.714
[B]<SIGNAL>IPD_PWR_HOLD</SIGNAL> [/B]diode 0.692

I don't want to blame <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> directly and since I need to order these chips and it requires a lot of time.. is there anything else I need to checkup? something I looked over?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message: Did you check diode mode to ground on all secondary power supplies?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message: Thanks for your response. I replaced the <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> chip and it successfully fixed the issue.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
This board after one month has returned.. customer complained the screen turned grey then it shut off.
I've received the computer, the board takes 5V 0.01-0.08A
[B]PPBUS[/B] 12.3V
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL>[/B] 3.8V
[B]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AON</SIGNAL> [/B]1.8V
[B]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2_MAIN</SIGNAL> [/B]5.1v
[B]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL> [/B]1.8v

<CHIP>U9300</CHIP> should produces three power stages and they're present at 2.5v
[B]P1V8VDDH_DRMOS_PWM1[/B] & [B]P1V8VDDH_DRMOS_PWM2[/B] & [B]P1V8VDDH_DRMOS_PWM3

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S1_CLVR_VDDH</SIGNAL> [/B]1.8v

[B]<CHIP>U8100</CHIP>[/B] bucks were present except for [B]PPVDD_AVEMSR_AWAKESW[/B] was missing on all coils and on both sides.

[B]PPVDD2H0_S2SW [/B]is present at 1v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
All USB-C ports have the same behavior?
Tested disconnecting internal LCD?

Check if machine can complete DFU revive.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
"All USB-C ports have the same behavior?"
yes exactly 

"Tested disconnecting internal LCD?"
I'm testing bare board 

"Check if machine can complete DFU revive." 
It won't go into DFU

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
Forcing is by wiring [B]<SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL>[/B] to [B]SOC_FORCE_DFU_DBG [/B]based on the test pads on board is that correct or have I gotten it wrong?
If yes then it won't go DFU either

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
The picture you're mentioning is for the M1 MacBook Air which has a different layout than the 14" MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. 

I spoke to Alexey to to get the numbers and orientation of the board correct for M1 Pro. 

Anyways, I have now 1.25v in <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> still not going into DFU.. I tried bare board and I tried in housing with battery and charger plugged in same results not getting into DFU..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message: idk why and idk how, computer booted..
